name: Fafda-Jalebi
description: A traditional Gujarati breakfast pairing of crisp, gram-flour sticks (fafda) and sweet, golden jalebi spirals. This combination perfectly balances savory crunch and syrupy sweetness, usually enjoyed on festive mornings like Dussehra.
preCookingProcess: In a bowl, mix besan, ajwain, turmeric, salt, and baking soda for fafda.
Add 2 tbsp oil and water gradually to make a firm dough.
Cover and let it rest for 10–15 minutes.
For jalebi, mix maida, curd, a pinch of baking soda, and a little water to form a thick batter.
Set aside to ferment for 30–40 minutes.

Make the fafda: Divide the dough into small portions and roll each into a thin long strip using the base of your palm on an oiled surface.
Heat oil in a kadai on medium-high heat and fry the strips until crisp and golden.
Drain on a paper towel to remove excess oil.
Prepare sugar syrup for jalebi: In a saucepan, combine sugar and 1/2 cup water.
Boil until it reaches one-string consistency.
Add lemon juice, saffron strands, and cardamom powder. Keep it warm (not boiling).
Make the jalebi: Pour the fermented batter into a piping bag or squeeze bottle.
Pipe out spirals into medium-hot oil or ghee.
Fry until golden and crisp on both sides.
Immediately dip the hot jalebis into the warm sugar syrup for a few seconds, then remove.
Serve together: Serve hot crispy fafda with freshly soaked jalebi spirals.
Optionally, pair with fried green chilies and raw papaya chutney.

postCookingProcess: Ensure both fafda and jalebi are served immediately for best texture contrast.
Store leftover jalebi in a sealed container at room temperature; reheat lightly before serving.
Fafda stays crisp if kept in an airtight container.
tipsAndTricks: Always fry fafda on medium heat to maintain crunchiness.
For perfect jalebi texture, ensure the batter is slightly fermented and piping consistency is correct.
Do not over-soak jalebi in syrup; a few seconds is enough.
